study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of aerobic exercise on pain, function, quality of life, psychological functioning, and adverse events compared to placebo, sham treatment, attention control, or no treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results; it is a protocol for a future Cochrane Review.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of treadmill exercise combined with metformin in improving cognitive impairment and its molecular mechanisms in T2DM rats.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise combined with metformin improved cognitive decline, reduced neuroinflammation, and promoted hippocampal neurogenesis in T2DM rats by upregulating the Wnt/β-catenin pathway.
population_specificity: T2DM rats induced by high-fat diet and low-dose streptozotocin.
effective_dosage: Treadmill exercise (specific dosage not detailed) and metformin (70 mg/kg).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of aerobic exercise combined with resistance training on metabolic markers in postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in HbA1c levels but noted a significant improvement in the HOMA-IR index, indicating some metabolic benefits. The certainty of evidence was very low, suggesting the need for further research.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: Exercise intervention ranged between two to four days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic exercise promotes cognitive recovery in a mouse model of vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) by modulating the ANXA1/MAPK axis.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved spatial memory, white matter integrity, and hippocampal function in BCAS mice by enhancing synaptic protein expression, reducing inflammation via ANXA1 upregulation, and suppressing MAPK signaling. These effects were linked to astrocyte polarization toward the A2 phenotype.
population_specificity: BCAS (bilateral common carotid artery stenosis) mice, a model for vascular cognitive impairment and dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a sub-symptom threshold aerobic exercise intervention on symptom burden and quality of life in adults with persistent post-concussive symptoms (PPCS) after mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).
results_summary: The 12-week aerobic exercise intervention significantly improved overall symptom burden, quality of life, dizziness, and exercise tolerance, with additional improvements in headache and depressive symptoms in the immediate intervention group. No changes were observed in autonomic function measures.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 42.6 years, 74% female) with PPCS and exercise intolerance, averaging 25.1 months post-mTBI.
effective_dosage: Sub-symptom threshold aerobic exercise (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence on the antidepressant effects of aerobic exercise in youth, investigate dose-response relationships, and provide insights for future research and clinical treatment.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise significantly reduced depressive symptoms in youth, with notable dose-response relationships observed across age, intensity, and duration of intervention. A moderate-intensity program (25-40 min, 3 times/week for 9-15 weeks) was most effective.
population_specificity: Youth (combined sample size of 1308 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically investigate the effects of aerobic exercise on quality of life, cognitive performance, and depressive symptoms in people with Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved cognitive function (MMSE and ADAS-cog scores) and quality of life but did not significantly affect depressive symptoms. Subgroup analysis indicated that longer durations (>16 weeks) and specific intervention lengths (30-50 min per session) yielded better outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD).
effective_dosage: More than three interventions per week, 30-50 min per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the optimal dose of aerobic exercise (using the FITT-VP model) needed to achieve clinically relevant pain reduction in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise showed significant pain reduction (MD -0.49; CI [-0.90, -0.08; p = 0.02]) with moderate to low heterogeneity. Tailored dosing (2-3 times weekly, 25-40 minutes per session, >100 minutes weekly) starting at low intensity and progressing over 6-12 weeks was recommended.
population_specificity: Fibromyalgia patients
effective_dosage: 2-3 times weekly, 25-40 minutes per session, >100 minutes weekly

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of physical exercise on pathological features of Alzheimer's disease (AD), including tau tangles, amyloid plaques, iron deposits, and ferroptosis in the hippocampal formation of aged rats.
results_summary: Physical exercise reduced inflammaging, improved axon-myelin volume relations, and showed beneficial effects on tau, amyloid, and iron levels in the hippocampal formation, suggesting a protective role against AD pathology.
population_specificity: Aged rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the dose-response association of aerobic exercise with adiposity measures in adults with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: Each 30 minutes per week of aerobic exercise was associated with modest reductions in body weight, waist circumference, and body fat percentage. Aerobic exercise exceeding 150 minutes per week at moderate intensity or greater was linked to clinically important reductions in waist circumference and body fat.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight or obesity (mean age 46 years, 61% female).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per week to 300 minutes per week of aerobic exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how different intensities of aerobic exercise reprogram the immune microenvironment of epididymal adipose tissue in nutritionally obese mice.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved morphology and blood indexes, reduced liver lipid content and adipose tissue inflammation, and decreased mRNA and protein expression of inflammatory markers. High-intensity intermittent exercise (HF-T) showed the most significant effects.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J male obese mice induced by a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity continuous exercise (HF-M), high-intensity continuous exercise (HF-H), and high-intensity intermittent exercise (HF-T) for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms by which aerobic exercise improves insulin sensitivity and reduces liver fat in MAFLD, focusing on exosomal pathways involving miR-324.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise significantly reduced liver fat and improved insulin sensitivity in MAFLD patients and HFD mice, with exosomal miR-324 identified as a key mediator targeting ROCK1. The study revealed an inverse association between miR-324 levels and insulin sensitivity, suggesting adipose tissue as its origin.
population_specificity: 15 MAFLD patients and high-fat diet (HFD) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of aerobic exercise on mood and brain function in emerging adults, a population susceptible to mental disorders.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic exercise was associated with changes in mood and brain function, as measured by mood scales and resting-state fMRI scans, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. The dataset provides a resource for further analysis of these effects.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 17 to 24.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise on a cycle ergometer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of combining transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) with low-intensity aerobic exercise on chronic fatigue in patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).
results_summary: The study found that tDCS combined with aerobic exercise significantly reduced chronic fatigue by approximately 60% in one patient, nearly double the improvement seen in the sham patient. The tDCS patient also showed improvements in physical activity, functional capacity, handgrip strength, daily activities, and sleep quality, while the sham patient experienced declines in physical activity and minimal fatigue improvement.
population_specificity: Two patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).
effective_dosage: Low-intensity aerobic exercise (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of aerobic exercise (AE) alone and in combination with progressive resisted exercise (PRE) on bone mineral density, muscular strength, exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life in patients with osteoporotic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
results_summary: The study found that AE combined with PRE was more beneficial than AE alone in improving knee muscle strength, exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life. AE alone did not significantly increase bone mineral density compared to the control group, but the combined group showed significant improvements.
population_specificity: 80 SLE patients aged 30-50 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-intensity inspiratory muscle training (H-IMT) alone and combined with aerobic and resistance training in reducing arterial stiffness (measured by baPWV) in individuals with stable COPD.
results_summary: The study is designed as a three-arm RCT to assess the impact of H-IMT and combined exercise on arterial stiffness, with primary outcomes measured at eight weeks and secondary outcomes tracked up to 32 weeks. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Individuals with stable COPD in a community setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obesity, dietary content, weight loss, and cortisol concentrations in postmenopausal women with overweight and obesity, specifically examining the effects of aerobic exercise combined with weight loss.
results_summary: The intervention resulted in significant weight loss (-8%) but no significant changes in basal cortisol or cortisol suppression after dexamethasone suppression test (DST). Basal glucose levels and glucose AUC were associated with basal cortisol levels.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with overweight and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of cocoa flavanols (CF) combined with aerobic exercise on glucose uptake and inflammatory mediators in insulin-resistant rats.
results_summary: CF combined with submaximal aerobic exercise improved glucose uptake, enhanced Akt and AMPK phosphorylation, reduced TRB3 gene expression, elevated CPT-1a gene expression, and ameliorated inflammation in multiple tissues of insulin-resistant rats.
population_specificity: Insulin-resistant Wistar rats (15 weeks old, 250 ± 10g) induced by a high-fat diet and fructose-rich beverage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week program of caloric restriction and aerobic exercise could improve PMS symptoms, anthropometric measures, and hormonal parameters in obese females with PMS.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of caloric restriction and aerobic exercise significantly improved PMS symptoms, reduced weight, BMI, waist and hip circumferences, W/H ratio, and serum cortisol levels, while increasing serum progesterone levels compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Obese females with premenstrual syndrome (PMS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (aerobic exercise program details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different types of acute aerobic exercise (moderate intensity, high cognitive-demand, and high physical-demand) affect inhibitory control compared to a rest condition.
results_summary: All interventions reduced reaction times in the Flanker task, with high physical-demand exercise showing greater reductions for both congruent and incongruent trials, and high cognitive-demand exercise improving reaction times specifically in incongruent trials. The study concluded that higher cognitive and physical engagement during exercise enhances inhibitory control more effectively than moderate exercise alone.
population_specificity: 25 young adults (mean age 20.20 years, SD=0.91).
effective_dosage: 20-minute sessions of each intervention (moderate intensity exercise, high cognitive-demand exercise, high physical-demand exercise, and rest).

study_goal: To examine the effects of long-term aerobic exercise on oxidative stress and learning memory ability in APP/PS1 mice, focusing on the hippocampal Keap1/Nrf2/GPX4 pathway.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise significantly improved cognitive function, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, ROS), and increased antioxidant activity (SOD, Nrf2, HO-1, GPX4) in the hippocampus of AD mice.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 double transgenic Alzheimer’s disease (AD) mice.
effective_dosage: Swimming training (specific duration/frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of HRV-Biofeedback training on recovery parameters after aerobic exercise in soccer players.
results_summary: The study found that HRV-Biofeedback training significantly shortened HRV recovery parameters after exercise, indicating faster cardiovascular recovery in athletes who underwent the training compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Twenty-four soccer players aged 18-24.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of HRV-Biofeedback training (specific duration per session not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether aerobic exercise attenuates insulin resistance by restoring branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) homeostasis and enhancing AMPK activity in diet-induced obese mice.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved insulin sensitivity, increased BCAAs catabolic protein expression, and reduced plasma BCAAs levels in obese mice. However, BCAAs supplementation counteracted these benefits by impairing insulin signaling and AMPK activity.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice with diet-induced obesity.
effective_dosage: 2% BCAAs in drinking water for supplemented groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effect of aerobic exercise training (AET) on myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury (MIRI) and its underlying mechanism involving m6A RNA methylation and the Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: AET improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial injury and fibrosis, and protected against MIRI by lowering m6A RNA methylation levels and modulating METTL3 expression. It also activated the Nrf2/HO-1 antioxidant pathway, mitigating MIRI.
population_specificity: Mouse model of MIRI and primary cardiomyocyte culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antihypertensive effects of aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance exercise, isometric resistance exercise, and combined exercise in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found that all types of exercise significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, with no significant differences in effectiveness between aerobic and resistance exercises. The reduction in blood pressure was clinically meaningful, with aerobic exercise showing comparable efficacy to resistance exercises.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients aged 18 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of aerobic exercise (AE) in reducing cardiovascular risk factors in female breast cancer patients and assess the quality of the synthesized evidence.
results_summary: The study found that AE reduced the incidence of cardiovascular disease events by 29.4% and coronary artery disease events by 36%, while also improving LVEF, reducing weight, and decreasing hip circumference. Subgroup analyses indicated nonlinear AE increased VO2max and reduced fat mass, while linear AE lowered LDL-C.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic exercise is beneficial in treating depression in adults.
results_summary: The review found substantial evidence supporting aerobic exercise's potential to alleviate depressive symptoms, with positive effects noted in both general depression and as an add-on intervention. Aerobic exercise also improved cardiorespiratory fitness and had neurobiological benefits in people with major depressive disorder.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of aerobic exercise on sleep disorders in menopausal women and propose an optimal exercise program based on frequency, duration, and form.
results_summary: Low- and moderate-intensity aerobic exercise had a moderate effect on improving sleep disorders in menopausal women, with optimal results seen at 3 times/week, 70-90 min/session, lasting 8-10 weeks, using static exercise and individual practice. Group exercise improved persistence but had lesser effects.
population_specificity: Menopausal women with sleep disorders

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the cardio-protective effects of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise and its mechanism in reducing myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury by modulating NLRP3.
results_summary: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial injury and inflammatory response, decreased myocardial infarction area, and lowered cell apoptosis in mice. It also reduced NLRP3 expression and inhibited apoptosis-related proteins and inflammatory factors.
population_specificity: C57BL/6N mice
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (50-70% VO2max) on a treadmill

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of aerobic exercise compared to other interventions in reducing pain intensity and disability in individuals with neck pain.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise alone was not statistically different from no-treatment or other interventions for pain intensity, but when combined with other therapies (e.g., strengthening exercises or acupuncture), it showed better results. The evidence was limited, low-quality, and heterogeneous.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years old with neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining ischemic preconditioning (IPC) with aerobic exercise enhances post-exercise hypotension (PEH) compared to aerobic exercise alone.
results_summary: The study found that IPC combined with aerobic exercise significantly reduced systolic blood pressure during sleep compared to exercise alone, with sustained baroreflex sensitivity (BRS) up to 24 hours post-exercise. No differences were observed in BP and heart rate responses during exercise and 1-hour recovery between conditions.
population_specificity: Twelve pre- or hypertensive men (six prehypertension, six stage 1 hypertension).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of aerobic exercise at 50% VO2peak.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of aerobic exercise on total hippocampal formation volume and subfield volumes in people with schizophrenia, as well as its clinical implications.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of aerobic exercise on total hippocampal formation volume, but original data suggested significant volume increases in specific subfields (cornu ammonis and dentate gyrus). The study highlights the need to focus on subfields and identify patient subgroups responsive to exercise.
population_specificity: People with schizophrenia (186 in meta-analysis, 29 in original data; 100 male, 86 female in meta-analysis; 20 male, 9 female in original data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Agmatine as an NMDA receptor antagonist in treating various neurological disorders.
results_summary: The study found that Agmatine, among other NMDA receptor antagonists, showed promising therapeutic effects in animal models of brain diseases such as stroke, epilepsy, and Alzheimer's disease. The results suggest potential neuroprotective properties and clinical benefits.
population_specificity: Animal models (mice) with neurological disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Irvingia gabonensis (African Mango) on metabolic syndrome (MetS), insulin sensitivity, and insulin secretion.
results_summary: African Mango administration led to significant reductions in waist circumference, glucose levels, triglycerides, VLDL, and glucose AUC, with 58.3% of treated patients showing remission of MetS compared to 16.7% in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 24 patients with metabolic syndrome (IDF criteria).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to highlight the rediscovery of agmatine as an endogenous ligand for α receptors, suggesting renewed interest in its physiological significance.
results_summary: The abstract mentions the rediscovery of agmatine as an endogenous ligand for α receptors, but no specific study results or effects are detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-inflammatory effects of agmatine as a potential therapeutic approach for major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that agmatine, along with other nutraceuticals, possesses anti-inflammatory effects that may contribute to antidepressant properties, but specific results for agmatine alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether agmatine could reduce ASD-like symptoms in a VPA-induced autism model in mice.
results_summary: Agmatine was among the agents that successfully reduced ASD-like symptoms in the VPA-induced model, though complete prevention of symptoms was rare. The abstract suggests agmatine affects brain neurotransmitters to achieve these effects.
population_specificity: Mouse offspring exposed to valproic acid (VPA) on postnatal day four.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic effects of arginine (Arg) and fluoride (F) toothpastes on supragingival plaque in adults with varying caries status.
results_summary: The study found that 14% of caries lesions became inactive after 12 weeks of treatment, with enamel lesions more likely to become inactive than dentin lesions. The metabolic profiles of plaque were analyzed, showing differences in arginine catabolism and acidogenicity between treatments.
population_specificity: 83 adults with different caries status (caries-free and carious tooth surfaces).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of agmatine in various CNS cell lines and animal models against multiple forms of neurotoxicity and injury.
results_summary: The study found that agmatine demonstrated significant neuroprotective effects against excitotoxicity, oxidative damage, corticosteroid-induced neurotoxicity, ischemic/hypoxic injury, spinal cord injury, and traumatic brain injury, as well as rescue of retinal ganglion cells. The effects were attributed to its multimolecular biological actions, including glutamatergic receptor antagonism.
population_specificity: CNS cell lines and animal models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore agmatine's role in regulating ion channels and receptors involved in CNS disorders and its potential therapeutic effects.
results_summary: Agmatine was found to regulate cell differentiation, nitric oxide synthesis, endothelial cell migration, and provide relief in chronic pain, cerebral edema, and apoptotic cell death in experimental CNS disorders. The study highlights agmatine's interaction with key CNS receptors and channels.
population_specificity: Experimental models of CNS disorders (murine brain endothelial cells and other preclinical settings).

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of LAT1 in transporting metabolites like agmatine and its potential as a drug target for cancer treatment.
results_summary: The abstract mentions LAT1's role in transporting metabolites, including agmatine, but does not provide specific findings on agmatine's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the specific mitochondrial functions of agmatine compared to other biologically active amines, particularly its role in reactive oxygen species production and apoptosis.
results_summary: The study suggests that agmatine, like spermine, has distinct mitochondrial functions, potentially influencing reactive oxygen species generation and apoptosis, which could be leveraged for therapeutic strategies, such as cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mitochondrial studies in liver, kidney, heart, and brain cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of replacing chicken or pork with herring on plasma metabolites, including agmatine, in obese individuals.
results_summary: The herring diet decreased plasma agmatine levels, suggesting an impact on arginine metabolism, supported by increased nitric oxide in males.
population_specificity: 15 healthy obese men and women aged 24-70 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (herring consumed as main protein source, five meals per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of agmatine as a neurotransmitter and its neuroprotective effects in brain injury.
results_summary: The study identified agmatine as a neurotransmitter in mammals and highlighted its potential neuroprotective effects in brain injury, suggesting its involvement in CNS functions.
population_specificity: Mammals (not further specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical phenotype of Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) and the anatomical and functional remodeling in RP, using studies from the rd/rd (rd1) mouse model.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Agmatine or its effects; it focuses on RP's clinical manifestations, retinal remodeling, and potential impacts on vision restoration strategies.
population_specificity: Human RP patients and rd/rd (rd1) mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of agmatine on CNS disorders and evaluate its potential as a pharmacological treatment for neurological and neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: Preclinical studies demonstrated beneficial effects of exogenous agmatine on depression, anxiety, hypoxic ischemia, nociception, morphine tolerance, memory, and various neurodegenerative disorders. The review highlighted agmatine's neuromodulatory and neuroprotective properties.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (animal models and in vitro research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the interactions and mechanisms of imidazoline receptors, including the role of endogenous ligands like agmatine, in physiological responses and toxicity.
results_summary: The study identified agmatine as one of the endogenous compounds binding to imidazoline receptors, but specific effects or outcomes related to agmatine were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the role of L-arginine metabolism in airway dysfunction in asthma and potential therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that alterations in L-arginine metabolism contribute to reduced NO formation and airway dysfunction in asthma, and modulating this metabolism may help correct airway tone and responsiveness.
population_specificity: Asthma patients (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the preclinical and initial clinical evidence for agmatine's therapeutic potential in treating complex diseases with unmet needs, such as diabetes, neurotrauma, and mood disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights agmatine's broad modulatory action on neurotransmitter systems, nitric oxide synthesis, and polyamine metabolism, suggesting therapeutic applications for various diseases. It also notes substantial preclinical and initial clinical evidence but acknowledges challenges and opportunities for further research.
population_specificity: Preclinical models and initial clinical studies (specific populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of agmatine in the central nervous system (CNS) and highlight its pharmacological actions in CNS disorders and drug development.
results_summary: The study found that agmatine has potential analgesic, anxiolytic, and antidepressant effects in animals, modulates learning and memory, and may help with cerebral damage and withdrawal syndromes. However, abnormal agmatine release may be linked to CNS disorders like schizophrenia.
population_specificity: Animal models (not specified further).
interactions: Interaction with glutamatergic and nitrergic systems noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical, biochemical, and molecular features of argininosuccinic aciduria (ASA) and discuss current treatments and future modalities, with a focus on the role of arginine and its metabolites, including agmatine.
results_summary: The study highlights that ASL deficiency leads to decreased arginine synthesis, affecting the production of agmatine and other metabolites, but does not specifically evaluate agmatine's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with argininosuccinic aciduria (ASA), a urea cycle disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and update the information on the effects of agmatine in the central nervous system (CNS) and highlight its pharmacological importance in central disorders.
results_summary: Agmatine exhibited anticonvulsant, antinociceptive, anxiolytic, and antidepressant-like actions in experimental studies, with beneficial effects on cerebral ischemia models and modulation of withdrawal syndromes for addictive agents. However, aberrant release of agmatine in the CNS may be associated with mechanisms of certain CNS disorders, such as psychosis.
population_specificity: Animal models and experimental studies (specific human population not mentioned).
interactions: Interactions with glutamatergic and nitrergic systems mentioned, but no specific medications, foods, or supplements noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of agmatine against rotenone-induced cellular injury in a human-derived dopaminergic neuroblastoma cell line (SH-SY5Y), focusing on mechanisms like oxidative stress reduction and mitochondrial preservation.
results_summary: Agmatine dose-dependently reduced rotenone-induced cellular injury by lowering oxidative stress, preventing mitochondrial dysfunction, and attenuating apoptotic markers like caspase 3 activity, Bax expression, and cytochrome c release. Unlike spermine, agmatine also inhibited nuclear factor-κB translocation, suggesting broader neuroprotective mechanisms.
population_specificity: Human-derived dopaminergic neuroblastoma cell line (SH-SY5Y).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could protect against ETEC infection and promote intestinal stem cell proliferation and differentiation via the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila reduced ETEC-induced intestinal inflammation, maintained Treg/Th17 cell balance, and stimulated intestinal epithelial proliferation and differentiation, with effects superior to Bacteroides fragilis. Its protective effects were reversed by a Wnt inhibitor, confirming pathway mediation.
population_specificity: Antibiotic-induced microbiome-disordered (AIMD) piglets, mice, and intestinal organoid models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of dietary agmatine sulfate in treating herniated lumbar disc-associated radiculopathy.
results_summary: Agmatine sulfate was found to be safe, with only mild-to-moderate gastrointestinal side effects at the highest dose. It significantly improved pain measures and quality of life compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Participants diagnosed with herniated lumbar disc-associated radiculopathy.
effective_dosage: 1.335 g/day, 2.670 g/day, 3.560 g/day for 10 days; 3.560 g/day for 21 days (dose escalation study); 2.670 g/day for 14 days (follow-up study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize a phyto-postbiotic (C-Akm) derived from chicory extract fermented by Akkermansia muciniphila, assessing its potential anti-inflammatory and anti-obesity effects.
results_summary: The C-Akm extract reduced ROS generation, pro-inflammatory cytokine expression (TNF-α, IL-6, INFγ, IL-17A), and leptin secretion while increasing adiponectin and HSL expression in adipocytes and co-culture models, demonstrating anti-inflammatory and anti-obesity potential.
population_specificity: In vitro models (THP-1 macrophages, LPS-stimulated PBMCs, human adipose stem cell-derived adipospheroids, and 3D co-culture mimicking inflamed obese adipose tissue).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how quercetin intervention, through boosting Akkermansia muciniphila colonization, reverses obesity-related phenotypes and influences bile acid metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that quercetin enriched Akkermansia muciniphila, leading to increased indole-3-lactic acid production, which upregulated CYP8B1 expression and facilitated cholesterol conversion to cholic acid, ultimately suppressing lipid accumulation via FXR activation in adipose tissue.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro model based on mechanistic focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) on ulcerative colitis (UC) and its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: AKK reduced colon tissue damage, alleviated oxidative stress and inflammation, upregulated Occludin-1 and SCFAs receptors, and promoted M1 to M2 macrophage polarization. Silencing FFAR2 reversed these protective effects, suggesting AKK acts via SCFAs-SLC52A2/FFAR2 pathways.
population_specificity: DSS-induced UC mouse model and LPS-treated THP-1-M0 and raw264.7 macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila and its metabolite propionate on Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology, focusing on mitochondrial homeostasis.
results_summary: The study found that AD patients had reduced Akkermansia muciniphila abundance and lower propionic acid levels. Administering A. muciniphila or propionate improved cognitive impairment, mitochondrial function, and mitophagy in AD mice.
population_specificity: AD patients (human) and AD model mice (animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether disulfiram (DSF) alleviates acetaminophen-induced acute liver injury (ALI) by modulating the gut microbiota, specifically focusing on the role of Akkermansia muciniphila.
results_summary: DSF restored intestinal microbiome balance by increasing Akkermansia muciniphila abundance, which alleviated ALI symptoms. A. muciniphila activated the PI3K/Akt pathway, corrected the Bcl-2/Bax ratio, and inhibited hepatocyte apoptosis.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal model based on methods described).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined therapeutic effects and immunomodulatory mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) and Clostridium butyricum (CB) in treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and colitis-associated colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: The co-administration of AKK and CB significantly alleviated IBD symptoms, regulated gut microbiota, suppressed colonic inflammation, and inhibited CRC progression. It also enhanced the efficacy of immunotherapy (anti-PD-L1) and improved survival rates in CRC mice.
population_specificity: DSS/AOM-induced IBD and colitis-associated CRC mice models.
interactions: Enhanced sensitivity to immune checkpoint inhibitor anti-mouse PD-L1 (aPD-L1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a mucoadhesive probiotic Akkermansia muciniphila-mimic nanotherapeutic (AM@HMPB@E) for ulcerative colitis (UC) treatment by repairing the intestinal barrier and scavenging reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (RONS).
results_summary: The study found that AM@HMPB@E exhibited exceptional retention in colitis sites and superior therapeutic efficacy compared to sulfasalazine, evidenced by longer colon length, reduced rectal bleeding, and less body weight loss. The nanotherapeutic effectively eliminated RONS, alleviated inflammation, and repaired the intestinal epithelial barrier.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models (specific human or animal details not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Akkermansia muciniphila (Akk) and pasteurized Akk (PA-Akk) on lipid absorption in the proximal intestine and its metabolic effects.
results_summary: Long-term administration of Akk reduced lipid deposits in the liver and adipocytes, improved glucose metabolism, and inhibited lipid absorption in the jejunum by activating AMPK. PA-Akk did not show the same effects on promoting core jejunal microbes.
population_specificity: Mice (and in vitro human jejunal epithelial cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in immune resistance in MAFLD-HCC patients and its potential as a predictive biomarker for PD1 response.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila administration reduced liver steatosis and tumor growth in MAFLD-HCC mouse models, repaired the intestinal lining, decreased serum LPS and bile acid metabolites, and reduced m-MDSCs and M2 macrophages. Combining Akk with PD1 treatment enhanced T-cell infiltration and activation, improving tumor suppression.
population_specificity: MAFLD-HCC mouse models and clinical correlation in MAFLD-HCC patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the correlation between Akkermansia muciniphila abundance and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) severity and metabolic indices, as well as evaluate the effects of AKK administration in a BPH mouse model.
results_summary: The study found reduced Akkermansia abundance in BPH patients, negatively correlated with symptom severity and metabolic markers. AKK administration in mice improved histopathology, reduced prostate index, and showed trends toward metabolic improvement, along with reduced inflammation and restored gut barrier integrity.
population_specificity: BPH patients and healthy donors (human study), testosterone-induced BPH mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the beneficial role of Akkermansia muciniphila in managing intestinal-related diseases and explore its potential mechanisms and clinical applications.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila plays a key role in managing intestinal inflammation, tumors, functional gastrointestinal disorders, and secondary conditions like liver and metabolic diseases, with potential for clinical treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of experimental and clinical studies)

study_goal: The researchers sought to investigate the therapeutic efficacy of different forms or strains of Akkermansia muciniphila in alleviating colitis and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Live Akkermansia muciniphila effectively reduced colitis in a DSS-induced mouse model by promoting IL-22 secretion and enhancing RA synthesis in dendritic cells, while heat-inactivated Akk did not show the same effect. The novel strain Am06 demonstrated efficacy similar to the reference strain.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila (pAKK) could serve as a safer and effective alternative to live AKK for treating preeclampsia by improving endothelial function and metabolic regulation.
results_summary: pAKK showed therapeutic effects comparable to live AKK in improving preeclampsia-like symptoms in mice, including enhanced gut barrier function, reduced endotoxemia, and restored placental angiogenesis via eNOS activity and NO production. Metabolomic analysis indicated pAKK reversed metabolic disturbances related to unsaturated fatty acid biosynthesis, folate, and linoleic acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Preeclampsia-induced mouse model and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila's outer membrane protein Amuc_1100 on NK cells in lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) and elucidate its potential molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that elevated AKK levels in LUAD patients correlated with increased NK cell infiltration and reduced TGF-β levels. Amuc_1100 treatment enhanced NK cell cytotoxicity, upregulated perforin and granzyme B, and inhibited cancer cell proliferation by suppressing the TGF-β pathway, also reducing tumor growth in vivo.
population_specificity: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) patients and a xenograft mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila on gut microbiota composition, inflammation, and metabolic complications in an obese-diabetic zebrafish model.
results_summary: Pasteurized A. muciniphila was found to be safe and potentially more cost-effective than live strains, with implications for obesity and diabetes management. The study suggests further investigation into its effects on metabolic pathways and inflammation.
population_specificity: Obese-diabetic zebrafish (Danio rerio) model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Akkermansia muciniphila modifies the association between prenatal metal exposures and depressive symptoms in childhood.
results_summary: A subgroup of children with prenatal exposure to zinc-chromium-cobalt had higher depression scores, but those with Akkermansia muciniphila in their gut microbiome showed significantly lower depression scores compared to those without it. The study suggests A. muciniphila may attenuate the depressive effects of prenatal metal exposure.
population_specificity: Children aged 9-11 years from a pediatric birth cohort (n = 112).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK ONE) on DSS-induced colitis in mice, focusing on its potential as a therapeutic agent for ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: AKK ONE supplementation improved food intake, weight, colon length, disease activity index, and intestinal barrier integrity in colitis mice. It also reduced inflammation by modulating cytokine levels and altered gut microbiota composition, increasing SCFAs in cecal contents.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and potential toxicity of a powder formulation of viable Akkermansia muciniphila (AMUC) in rats, following OECD protocols, to assess its suitability as a food ingredient.
results_summary: The study found no mortality, adverse effects, or bacterial translocation at doses up to 2000 mg/kg/day (1.64 × 10^11 CFU/kg/day), establishing a no-observed-adverse-effect level at the highest dose. AMUC (viable and nonviable) showed no mutagenic, clastogenic, or genotoxic effects in the tested assays.
population_specificity: Rats
effective_dosage: 0, 500, 1000, and 2000 mg/kg body weight/day (equivalent to 0, 4.1 × 10^10, 9.2 × 10^10, and 1.64 × 10^11 CFU/kg/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could prevent cognitive impairments and anxiety-related behavior in tau protein-induced Alzheimer's Disease (AD) rats by modulating the gut-brain axis.
results_summary: A. muciniphila significantly reduced anxiety-like behavior, improved spatial and recognition memory, and decreased pro-inflammatory cytokine levels (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, IFN-γ) in AD rats compared to untreated AD rats.
population_specificity: Tau protein-induced Alzheimer's Disease (AD) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila increases intestinal secretory IgA (SIgA) production in early-weaned piglets and mice.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila significantly increased SIgA levels, SIgA-coated bacteria abundance, and IgA+ plasma cell counts in mice, and similarly enhanced intestinal SIgA concentrations in piglets. It also altered the SIgA-coated bacterial landscape.
population_specificity: Early-weaned piglets (Huanjiang miniature and Duroc×Landrace×Yorkshire breeds) and male specific pathogen-free C57BL/6J mice.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat-killed Akkermansia muciniphila could improve gut microbiota diversity, metabolic signaling, and blood glucose levels in a mouse model of type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that heat-killed A. muciniphila increased gut microbiota diversity, elevated immune and metabolic signaling pathways, and promoted insulin-like growth factor 2 (IGF2) secretion, leading to improved muscle and global metabolism in diabetic mice.
population_specificity: Mice with streptozotocin (STZ)-induced type 1 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and underlying mechanism of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) in obesity-associated atherosclerosis and its potential therapeutic effects.
results_summary: AKK supplementation reduced atherosclerotic lesion formation, improved dyslipidemia, enhanced cardiac function, reduced body weight, modulated inflammatory cytokines (lowered IL-6, increased IL-10), and regulated gut microbiota by increasing Lactobacillaceae abundance.
population_specificity: ApoE-/- mice (a model for atherosclerosis) and human fecal samples from healthy controls and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ACVD) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on liver fibrosis and hyperammonemia in a murine model of liver cirrhosis.
results_summary: Administration of Akkermansia muciniphila improved liver fibrosis and hyperammonemia, with changes in bacterial composition in the small intestine, suggesting its potential as a microbial intervention for liver cirrhosis.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) model of liver cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel delivery system (AKK@GPMGs) for Akkermansia muciniphila to enhance its therapeutic effects in treating ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: AKK@GPMGs significantly improved resistance to stomach acid, intestinal colonization, reactive oxygen species scavenging, mucus layer thickness, goblet cell abundance, and gut microbiota balance while reducing intestinal permeability and inflammation. The microgels effectively released AKK@PMP at inflammatory sites, providing long-term adherence and synergistic therapy for UC.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical or animal model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila extracellular vesicles (AmEVs) protect against hypertension by modulating gene expression in the kidneys of spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).
results_summary: AmEVs protected against hypertension in SHRs without serious adverse reactions and modulated the expression of vasocontracting and vasodilating genes in the kidneys of both SHRs and Wistar-Kyoto rats (WKYs). The results suggest AmEVs could be a novel therapeutic for hypertension.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) and Wistar-Kyoto rats (WKYs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in delaying castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) and its potential therapeutic effects via the LPS/NF-κB/AR axis.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila enrichment was associated with delayed CRPC progression, linked to increased serum inosine levels. Supplementing inosine improved intestinal barrier function, reduced LPS levels, and inhibited CRPC via the LPS/NF-κB/AR pathway.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients and mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the influence of Akkermansia muciniphila and its derivatives on gastrointestinal and metabolic disorders through a meta-analysis of mouse model studies.
results_summary: A. muciniphila and its derivatives improved systemic and gut inflammation, liver enzyme levels, glycemic response, and lipid profiles, while also enhancing gut permeability. Live bacteria had a more substantial effect on most biomarkers, and gut microbiome analysis identified beneficial microbial clusters.
population_specificity: Mouse models of gastrointestinal and metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila and photobiomodulation (PBM) on promoting anti-inflammatory M2 macrophage polarization in gliadin-stimulated THP-1 derived macrophages.
results_summary: The study found that PBM combined with A. muciniphila increased anti-inflammatory cytokines (TGF-β, IL-10) and modulated inflammatory responses in gliadin-stimulated macrophages, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for celiac disease.
population_specificity: THP-1 derived human macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in Akkermansia muciniphila abundance in response to exercise across various study designs in humans and rodents.
results_summary: Human studies showed mixed results, with some reporting increases, others decreases, and no significant differences in A. muciniphila abundance, while rodent studies consistently demonstrated an increase in A. muciniphila following aerobic exercise.
population_specificity: Humans (522 participants, including 157 athletes) and rodents (310 animals, mostly mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the beneficial effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on various diseases and summarize its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila regulates metabolic and immune functions, protects gut health, and is associated with improvements in diseases like obesity, type 2 diabetes, and inflammatory conditions. Beneficial effects were observed not only with live bacteria but also with pasteurized forms, extracellular vesicles, and other derivatives.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of multiple studies, including animal and preclinical models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) in mitigating the effects of ischemic stroke, particularly its impact on neuroinflammation and neuronal damage.
results_summary: The study found that AKK administration improved body weight, reduced infarct volumes, decreased degenerating neurons and apoptotic cells, and lowered neuroinflammation by reducing astrocyte and microglia activation while upregulating anti-inflammatory factors in mice following ischemic stroke.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to ischemic stroke via a rose bengal photothrombosis model.
study_duration: Administered prior to stroke surgery, with outcomes assessed at 3 days post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify herbal drug extracts that promote the growth of Akkermansia muciniphila and assess their potential to improve metabolic health in obese mice.
results_summary: Five herbal extracts increased A. muciniphila DNA levels, with Dioscoreae rhizoma extract notably enhancing its growth in high-fat-diet mice, reducing weight gain, and improving glucose tolerance. The findings suggest A. muciniphila-boosting herbal extracts could be a therapeutic strategy for metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet (dietary obesity model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in gut health and its potential as a therapeutic target for intestinal diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila has beneficial effects in various diseases, including diabetes, obesity, aging, cancer, and metabolic syndrome, and may enhance intestinal barrier integrity. It is recognized as a promising probiotic for gut health.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of potential applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to sequence and analyze the genome of Akkermansia muciniphila ONE (AKK ONE) and evaluate its safety through toxicological studies.
results_summary: The study found that AKK ONE has a well-characterized genome with no detected virulence-related genes, is non-pathogenic, and shows good safety in toxicological tests. It demonstrated gastroenteric fluid tolerance but weak gut colonization ability.
population_specificity: Mice (toxicological studies)
study_duration: Not specified (acute and subchronic toxicity tests)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) plays a role in the therapeutic effects of Liangxue Guyuan Yishen Decoction (LGYD) on radiation-induced intestinal injury (RIII) by modulating gut microbiota and short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) production.
results_summary: The study found that LGYD increased AKK abundance and SCFA levels, particularly isobutyric acid, which correlated with improved recovery from RIII. AKK treatment enhanced survival rates, intestinal structure restoration, and intestinal stem cell function in organoid models.
population_specificity: Radiation-exposed subjects (in vivo and organoid models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Akkermansia muciniphila and its metabolite PEA in enhancing oxaliplatin efficacy in gastric cancer.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila promotes oxaliplatin efficacy by producing pentadecanoic acid (PEA), which inhibits glycolysis in cancer cells, thereby enhancing chemotherapy response. Fecal microbiota transplantation and metabolomics confirmed these effects.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the factors and molecular mechanisms by which Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) and its outer membrane protein Amuc_1100 affect immune escape in lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD).
results_summary: AKK and Amuc_1100 enhanced CD8+ T cell recruitment and toxicity, suppressed PD-L1 and JAK/STAT pathway proteins, and increased immune markers (CCL5, granzyme B, INF-γ), demonstrating antitumor effects in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) cell lines (A549, NCI-H1395) and a subcutaneous graft tumor mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) plays a role in the antidepressant effects of Hypericum perforatum L. (HPL) by modulating gut microbiota and tryptophan metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that HPL enriched AKK, which increased serotonin (5-HT) levels and reduced kynurenine (KYN), alleviating depression symptoms by modulating the NFκB-NLRP2-Caspase1-IL1β pathway. Mono-colonization with AKK replicated these effects, confirming its role in HPL's antidepressant mechanism.
population_specificity: CRS-induced depression model mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the roles of Akkermansia muciniphila in various health domains, including metabolic, inflammatory, and neurodegenerative diseases, and its potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila plays a key role in gut integrity, immune modulation, and metabolic processes, with potential benefits for obesity, diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and neuropsychiatric conditions. Challenges in practical application due to stability and cultivation issues were noted, but pasteurized forms and synthetic mediums offer new clinical possibilities.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of animal and preliminary human studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Akkermansia muciniphila in alleviating diabetic cognitive impairment (DCI) in db/db mice and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Live A. muciniphila significantly improved cognitive impairments, synaptic ultrastructure, and reduced hippocampal neuron loss, while both live and pasteurized forms mitigated neuroinflammation. The effects were linked to alterations in gut microbiota and serum/brain metabolites, particularly in tryptophan metabolism and related pathways.
population_specificity: Eleven-week-old db/db mice (a model for diabetes and cognitive impairment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could improve gut health and protect against ETEC infection in weaned piglets, evaluating both live and heat-killed forms at different dosages.
results_summary: A. muciniphila supplementation reduced diarrhea rates, improved intestinal morphology, enhanced immune response (CD4+ T lymphocytes), and lowered ETEC virulence gene expression, with the live low-dose (LA) group showing the most significant benefits. However, the heat-killed low-dose (LIA) group had a higher diarrhea rate than controls.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (28 days old)
effective_dosage: Live A. muciniphila (1 × 10^10 CFU/5 mL and 5 × 10^8 CFU/5 mL) and heat-killed A. muciniphila (same doses), administered every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on pancreatic β-cell function, apoptosis, differentiation, and related mechanisms in a prediabetic rat model.
results_summary: Both A. muciniphila and dietary intervention reduced metaflammation, repaired the intestinal barrier, and improved β-cell function, apoptosis, and differentiation via TLR2 and TLR4 signaling pathways. A. muciniphila further enhanced these effects beyond dietary intervention alone.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced prediabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether engineered Lactococcus lactis producing P9 protein from Akkermansia muciniphila could stimulate GLP-1 release and improve glucose homeostasis.
results_summary: The study found that recombinant L. lactis NZP9 successfully secreted P9 protein, which stimulated GLP-1 production in NCI-H716 cells and upregulated GLP-1 biosynthesis genes. The results suggest potential therapeutic applications for diabetes and obesity.
population_specificity: HFD-induced mice and NCI-H716 cells (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila and its outer membrane proteins on gastric cancer, focusing on apoptosis, immune modulation, and tumor growth inhibition.
results_summary: AKK and its outer membrane proteins promoted apoptosis in gastric cancer cells, stimulated immune responses (M1 macrophage polarization, cytotoxic T-lymphocyte activation, and Treg suppression), and inhibited tumor growth while enhancing immune cell infiltration in tumor tissues.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer models (in vitro and in vivo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the probiotic Lactiplantibacillus fermentum F6 could modulate Akkermansia muciniphila levels and ameliorate colitis in a rat model.
results_summary: The study found that administering the probiotic reduced Akkermansia muciniphila levels in colitis rats and improved colitis symptoms, including lower disease activity scores and inflammatory markers. The results suggest the probiotic's mechanism may involve targeted reduction of specific gut microbes linked to disease.
population_specificity: Dextran sulfate sodium-induced colitis rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic potential of combining Akkermansia muciniphila with inosine in alleviating alcohol-induced liver injury by improving gut-liver axis function and immune modulation.
results_summary: The combination of Akkermansia muciniphila and inosine significantly reduced liver injury markers, improved intestinal barrier function, restored gut microbiota balance, and modulated immune responses, particularly by enhancing Treg cell functionality and reducing Th1/Th17 imbalance. These effects were partly dependent on A2AR activation.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice with alcohol-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila (Akk) supplementation could improve Parkinson's disease (PD) symptoms and neuroprotection in a mouse model.
results_summary: Akk treatment reduced dopaminergic neuron loss, improved motor function, alleviated neuroinflammation, promoted hippocampal neurogenesis, and decreased colon inflammation, likely linked to changes in serum and fecal isovaleric acid levels and lower intestinal permeability.
population_specificity: MPTP-induced subacute PD model mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between gastrointestinal reactive oxygen species (ROS), dietary antioxidants, and the beneficial gut bacterium Akkermansia muciniphila.
results_summary: The study found that A. muciniphila was more abundant in lean mice and negatively correlated with GI ROS levels. Grape polyphenols, but not other antioxidants, stimulated A. muciniphila growth, likely due to their poor bioavailability enhancing radical scavenging in the GI tract.
population_specificity: Lean and obese mice (n = 7 per group for comparison, n = 20 for intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila extracellular vesicles (AmEVs) have a protective effect against hypertension and their potential mechanism of action.
results_summary: AmEVs protected against hypertension development in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) without serious adverse reactions, increased T regulatory (Treg) cell populations, and tended to reduce proinflammatory cytokines. No effect was observed on vascular contraction or endothelial relaxation in thoracic aortas.
population_specificity: Wistar-Kyoto rats (WKYs) and spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe and discuss the mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila as an intestinal microbiota or probiotic in colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: The role of A. muciniphila in CRC development or inhibition remains unclear and controversial, with some studies suggesting increased abundance in CRC patients while others associate decreased abundance with severe symptoms. Preliminary human data indicate oral consumption is safe, but efficacy requires further clinical confirmation.
population_specificity: CRC patients and healthy individuals (comparative analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of diosmin (DIO) on Akkermansia muciniphila abundance and its role in improving intestinal barrier function and reducing inflammation in DSS-induced colitis.
results_summary: DIO administration increased A. muciniphila abundance and MUC2 expression while reducing oxidative stress and inflammation, improving intestinal barrier integrity via regulation of NF-κB, Nrf2, PIK3R3, and ZO-1 pathways.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with DSS-induced colitis
effective_dosage: 100 and 200 mg/kg of DIO, orally for 7 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Akkermansia muciniphila as a probiotic to mitigate olanzapine-induced weight gain and metabolic side effects.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila improved weight gain, insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, liver function, systemic inflammation, and gut barrier function in both mice models and clinical populations, demonstrating efficacy in reducing antipsychotic-induced metabolic impairment.
population_specificity: Psychiatric patients and mice models treated with second-generation antipsychotics (specifically olanzapine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila modifies the association between prenatal metal exposures and depressive symptoms in late childhood.
results_summary: The study found that in children without A. muciniphila, a metal-clique (Zinc-Chromium-Cobalt) was strongly associated with increased depression scores, whereas in children with A. muciniphila, the same metal-clique was weakly associated with decreased depression scores. This suggests A. muciniphila may attenuate the depressive effects of prenatal metal exposure.
population_specificity: 9-11-year-old children from a longitudinal birth cohort and microbiome substudy (n=112).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the curative effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on colitis-induced inflammation and enteric nervous system degeneration.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that A. muciniphila ameliorated inflammation and ENS damage in a TNBS-induced chronic colitis model, suggesting potential benefits for IBD treatment.
population_specificity: TNBS-induced chronic colitis model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the characteristics, diversity, and mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila, focusing on its potential therapeutic effects in infectious diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila has beneficial effects, including anti-cancer properties, immune modulation, and protection of intestinal barrier integrity, but its role in infectious diseases remains unclear.
population_specificity: Human gut microbiome (general population, not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential of pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila for alleviating IBS-like symptoms in mouse models and explore its neuromodulatory effects.
results_summary: Pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila significantly reduced colonic hypersensitivity, reinforced intestinal barrier function, improved anxiety-like behavior and memory defects, and exhibited neuroinhibitory effects on stimulated neuronal cells.
population_specificity: C57BL6/J mice with IBS-like symptoms induced by neonatal maternal separation or Citrobacter rodentium infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the contradictory roles of Akkermansia muciniphila in colorectal cancer, exploring how its administration could either protect against or exacerbate the disease.
results_summary: The study found conflicting results regarding A. muciniphila's role in colorectal cancer, with some models showing protective effects and others indicating increased tumor burden. Differences in experimental protocols, bacterial viability, and immunomodulatory effects of surface antigens were suggested as potential explanations.
population_specificity: Mice (animal models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could alleviate radiation-induced intestinal damage and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that A. muciniphila abundance decreased after abdominal irradiation, and its administration mitigated intestinal damage and improved survival in mice. Propionic acid, a metabolite of A. muciniphila, was identified as the key mediator of these protective effects by enhancing intestinal barrier integrity.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to abdominal irradiation and human patients receiving abdominal radiotherapy.
interactions: Metformin was noted to increase A. muciniphila abundance and improve intestinal barrier integrity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila enhances the efficacy of PD-1 monoclonal antibody therapy in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila improved PD-1mAb efficacy in HCC by promoting tumor cell apoptosis, increasing CD8+ T cell proportion, downregulating PD-L1 expression, and altering bile acid metabolism, notably increasing serum TUDCA levels.
population_specificity: Tumor-bearing mouse model (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila mediates the protective effects of astaxanthin (AST) in chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS) and its role in alleviating inflammation and pain.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila levels were reduced in CP/CPPS patients and EAP mice, and oral AST increased its abundance, which correlated with reduced inflammation and pain. Supplementation with A. muciniphila alone also alleviated symptoms in EAP mice.
population_specificity: Experimental autoimmune prostatitis (EAP) mice and CP/CPPS patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could improve LPS-induced acute lung injury by affecting gut microbiota and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: A. muciniphila attenuated lung tissue damage, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, maintained intestinal barrier function, reshaped gut microbiota, and promoted SCFA secretion, particularly butyrate, which downregulated the TLR2/MyD88/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced acute lung injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila-derived extracellular vesicles (Akk EVs) could modulate the intestinal barrier, reduce inflammation, and prevent colitis.
results_summary: Akk EVs reduced inflammatory markers (NO, TNF-α, IL-1β) in LPS-induced cells, improved intestinal barrier function (increased MUC2 expression, reduced permeability), and modulated gut microbiota (increased Firmicutes, decreased Proteobacteria) in a DSS-induced colitis mouse model.
population_specificity: LPS-induced RAW264.7 cells and DSS-induced colitis mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Akkermansia muciniphila and its extracellular vesicles in improving intestinal and blood-brain barrier function and mitigating postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) in mice.
results_summary: Supplementation with Akkermansia muciniphila or its extracellular vesicles improved cognitive function, enhanced gut and blood-brain barrier integrity, reduced inflammation, and inhibited microglial activation via TLR2/4 signaling in POCD mice. However, these benefits were absent in microglial-ablated mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 J mice with induced postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) via intestinal ischemia-reperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lycium barbarum, yam, and chrysanthemum polysaccharides (LYC) could improve drug-induced liver injury (DILI) by increasing the abundance of Akkermansia muciniphila.
results_summary: LYC increased A. muciniphila abundance in vitro and in antibiotic-treated mice, improved intestinal barrier function, reduced inflammation, and repaired DILI by upregulating hepatic YAP1 expression. The optimal concentration ratio for LYC was 1:1:1.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice (APAP-induced DILI model) and KM mice (antibiotic-treated).
effective_dosage: Optimal ratio for LYC was 1:1:1 (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of oral administration of Akkermansia muciniphila on alcoholic liver disease (ALD) by examining its effects on gut microbiota and host metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that A. muciniphila alleviated alcohol-induced liver injury, improved serum levels of ornithine, reduced oxalic acid levels, inhibited harmful bacteria proliferation, and promoted beneficial bacteria growth. These effects suggest A. muciniphila restores ALD by regulating gut microbiota and altering serum metabolism.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with induced ALD using a modified NIAAA model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could improve cardiac fibrosis (CF) induced by Trichinella spiralis infection in mice.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila was more abundant in Ts-infected mice and that oral supplementation (alive or pasteurized) improved CF via TLR2 signaling. Fecal microbiota transplantation also ameliorated CF, suggesting a causative role for gut microbiota in disease progression.
population_specificity: Ts-infected mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila and its outer membrane protein Amuc_1100 could alleviate high-fat diet-induced NAFLD in mice by modulating the gut-liver axis and gut microbiota.
results_summary: A. muciniphila and Amuc_1100 significantly reduced body weight, serum ALT and AST levels, improved lipid profiles, lowered LPS concentration, enhanced gut barrier function, and reduced liver inflammation in NAFLD mice, with effects comparable to atorvastatin. The treatment also altered gut microbiota composition, increasing beneficial bacteria and reducing harmful ones.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced NAFLD mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Akkermansia muciniphila contributes to improved glucose metabolism and reduced obesity, particularly in the context of isoxanthohumol (IX) administration.
results_summary: The study found that IX administration increased Akkermansia muciniphila abundance, which was linked to improved glucose metabolism, reduced CD36 expression in the jejunum, and decreased plasma fatty acid levels. Monocolonization of A. muciniphila in germ-free mice replicated these metabolic benefits.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed mice, including antibiotic-treated and germ-free mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in colorectal cancer (CRC) development and its molecular mechanism involving tryptophan-mediated AhR/β-catenin signaling.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila inhibited CRC formation by down-regulating tryptophan-mediated AhR signaling, and its antitumor effects were abolished in AhR-deficient models, suggesting a specific mechanism of action.
population_specificity: Mice models (AOM/DSS and ApcMin/+) and human colon cancer tumor models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in tumorigenesis and tumor therapy, focusing on its potential as a next-generation probiotic.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila's components and metabolites can influence tumorigenesis, particularly through antitumor immunosurveillance, and may improve outcomes in cancer prevention and treatment. It highlights the bacterium's potential as a therapeutic agent in both gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal cancers.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of potential applications in cancer therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila, in combination with glutamine, could mitigate renal interstitial fibrosis (RIF) by modulating gut microbiota and reducing kidney apoptosis.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila colonization, along with glutamine supplementation, effectively reduced cell apoptosis and renal fibrosis in a mouse model of unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO). SPX treatment increased A. muciniphila levels and modulated glutamine-related metabolism, contributing to renal protection.
population_specificity: Mice with unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO) as a model for renal interstitial fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila controls glycemia via a gut-brain axis and impacts gut motility in a high-fat diet mouse model.
results_summary: Pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila improved metabolic parameters (body weight, fat mass, insulin, glycemia, glucose tolerance) by reducing duodenal contraction and increasing hypothalamic nitric oxide release in high-fat diet mice.
population_specificity: Mice fed a 45% high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the proposed roles and mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila in neuropsychiatric disorders and explore its potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila improves symptoms of neuropsychiatric disorders by restoring gut microbiota, enhancing gut barrier integrity, and modulating immunity and inflammation, though it may also exacerbate inflammation in some cases. The exact mechanisms remain controversial.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of clinical and preclinical studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on the human immune system and its potential to enhance cancer immunotherapy by improving efficacy and reducing side effects.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila significantly inhibits carcinogenesis, improves anti-tumor effects, and enhances the effectiveness of cancer immunotherapy while reducing the likelihood of side effects. The review highlights its potential clinical applications in anti-tumor therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on correlations between Akkermansia muciniphila and neuropsychological diseases, focusing on its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study highlights A. muciniphila's role in neuropsychological diseases, emphasizing its outer membrane proteins as potential therapeutic targets, supported by evidence from animal and clinical studies.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could inhibit Fusobacterium nucleatum's effects and alleviate periodontitis.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila inhibited F. nucleatum's virulence gene expression and reduced inflammatory effects on gingival epithelial cells by modulating the TLR/MyD88/NF-κB pathway. Animal experiments confirmed A. muciniphila's ability to inhibit F. nucleatum-induced periodontitis in mice.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice and in vitro gingival epithelial cells (GECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Akkermansia muciniphila could prevent NAFLD, its mechanisms of action, and its effects on gut microbiota modulation.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila attenuated weight gain, insulin resistance, liver lipid deposition, and pro-inflammatory factors while improving gut barrier function and modulating beneficial microbiota. It also activated hepatic FXR and suppressed intestinal FXR.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet for 20 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in gut microbiota alterations and its potential benefits in reducing body fat and improving intestinal barrier function.
